Limits.description: Limits describe the behavior of a function as the input approaches a particular value. This concept is fundamental for defining continuity and derivatives. Common limit rules include sum, product, quotient, and squeeze theorem.

Basic Derivative Rules.description: Basic rules for differentiating functions, including the power rule, product rule, and quotient rule. These help compute derivatives efficiently.

Parametric Equations.description: Parametric equations express the coordinates of points on a curve as functions of a parameter, usually denoted as $t$. Useful for describing motion and curves.

Tangents and Velocity.description: Tangents represent the slope of a curve at a point, and velocity is the rate of change of position with respect to time. Both concepts rely on derivatives.

Derivative Function (Limit Definition).description: The derivative can be defined as the limit of the difference quotient: $f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}$. This formal definition is used to calculate derivatives.

Continuity.description: A function is continuous if it has no breaks, jumps, or holes in its graph. Mathematically, a function is continuous at $x = c$ if $\lim_{x \to c} f(x) = f(c)$.

Related Rates.description: Related rates problems involve finding the rate at which one quantity changes with respect to another, using the chain rule for differentiation. Solving real-world problems.

Linear Approximation.description: Linear approximation uses the tangent line at a point to estimate the value of a function near that point, based on $f(x) \approx f(a) + f'(a)(x - a)$.

Maximum and Minimum Values.description: Maximum and minimum values of a function occur at critical points where the derivative is zero or undefined. These points can be found using the first and second derivative tests.

Parameterized Equations and Curves.description: Parametric equations define curves by expressing coordinates as functions of a parameter. These equations are useful for analyzing the motion of objects along paths.

Further Derivative Rules.description: Advanced derivative rules such as the chain rule and implicit differentiation. These rules allow for the differentiation of more complex functions.
